image.alt: Jordan in our Medicine Man gallery, sharing all his knowledge.

content.text: It’s time again for us to present one of our glorious Visitor Experience Assistants. This time we meet Jordan. Brought up in Somerset, Jordan has lived in London for seven years and has worked in some of the capital’s top visitor attractions, including Buckingham Palace and the National Army Museum before joining us here at Wellcome Collection. Spending his working life in galleries doesn’t deter him from snooping around as many other museums as possible in his spare time. His current favourite is the Grant Museum’s permanent collection.
It still has that old Victorian atmosphere – exposed wood and plaster, taxidermy, clutter, that ‘old’ smell that you don’t get in most other modern museums

Jordan has been a VEA for just over three years and has an educational background in history, so it’s no surprise that his favourite object in the collection is one of our most historically loaded: Napoleon’s toothbrush.
It encapsulates Henry’s entire collection to me: it’s medical, random, bizarre and it invokes a variety of reactions from visitors.
Indeed, giving Medicine Man tours is when Jordan is in his element, teasing out the esoteric and complex stories of these cultural objects.

The man after which our institution is named casts a long shadow over us and we often have to consider the cultural or historical ramifications of telling his story. Despite our growing understanding of the issues around Henry’s attitudes to global cultures, Jordan still admires his dedication to bringing together the medical history of humankind.

I respect his desire for knowledge. Whilst Henry was very select in who got to access his knowledge and collections, he at least demonstrated a desire to try to understand and appreciate how different cultures and civilisations approached health and wellbeing and how we can all learn from one another. I think I share this trait a bit, since I love talking about different objects from around the world and I believe that bridging the gap between ‘us’ and ‘them’ is important in museums.

Aside from his interest in medical history, Jordan is a formidable authority on the multi-faceted world of international football and a deep explorer of the labyrinthine corridors of all things Science-Fiction. Very occasionally the circle of Sci-Fi celebrity intersects with his working day.

As an avid geek, seeing certain Game of Thrones stars come in to the museum is fun, but I achieved my ambition of seeing Gillian Anderson at last, who is still every bit as amazing as she was in the X-Files.
Rob is a Visitor Experience Assistant at Wellcome Collection.
